TextEquiv.Unicode: what one notices between the sexes of many butterﬂies. The diﬀerent form of the wing in the sexes of birds appears rarely to be noted, the mere length being recorded. The radius and ulna in the male are longer and the depression in front of their junction with the humerus deeper than in the female, the primary coverts are less exposed in the male, whilst the second, third, and fourth longer primaries are emarginate in front, in the male; but only the second and third, in the female; in the latter sex the primaries are more perfectly graded, whereas in the male the outer edge forms a slight sinus; the tail diﬀers much in outline, as will be at once seen from the cut.

Young birds are very like the female. After the autumn moult the feathers of the crown and breast have greyish borders, the crimson being dull and presenting a mottled appearance; this (in fully adult males) gradually changes to the bright colouring at the approach of spring.*
This species, which is variously called the Grey, Brown, or Red Linnet, according to the age or plumage of the specimens so named, during the summer

* Seebohm almost always explains this change of colouring, by asserting that the tips of the feathers drop oﬀ; but if one obtains a bird in its transition stage the tips are frequently neither dropped nor abraded, although undoubtedly in some species the edges are worn oﬀ, whilst in others the colouring alters in the feathers themselves.
